deck.name: Rider-Waite Tarot

entries: The {@link Rider-Waite Tarot|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rider%E2%80%93Waite_Tarot} is a widely popular deck for tarot card reading, first published by {@link William Rider & Son|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rider_(imprint)} in 1909, based on the instructions of academic and mystic {@link A. E. Waite|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A._E._Waite} and illustrated by {@link Pamela Colman Smith|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pamela_Colman_Smith}, both members of the {@link Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hermetic_Order_of_the_Golden_Dawn}. Also known as the Waite-Smith, Rider-Waite-Smith, or Rider Tarot, the deck has been published in numerous editions and inspired a wide array of variants and imitations. Estimates suggest over 100 million copies of the deck circulate across over 20 countries.

entries.name: Overview
entries: The Rider-Waite tarot deck has 78 cards: 56 {@link Minor Arcana|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minor_Arcana}, and 22 {@link Major Arcana|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major_Arcana}. The Minor Arcana generally correspond to the suits of {@link Spanish|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spanish-suited_playing_cards} or {@link Italian playing cards|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_playing_cards}. The Major Arcana, corresponding to the {@link trump cards|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trump_(card_games)} of gaming tarot, have unique designs numbered from 0 ({@link The Fool|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Fool_(tarot_card)}) to 21 ({@link The World|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_World_(tarot_card)}).

While the images are simple, the details and backgrounds feature abundant symbolism. Some imagery remains similar to that found in earlier decks, but overall the Waite-Smith card designs are substantially different from their predecessors. Christian imagery was removed from some cards, and added to others. For example, the 'Papess' became the 'High Priestess' and no longer features a Papal tiara. The 'Lovers' card, previously depicting a medieval scene of a clothed man and woman receiving a blessing from a noble or cleric was changed to a depiction of the naked {@link Adam and Eve|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adam_and_Eve} in the {@link Garden of Eden|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garden_of_Eden}, and the ace of cups featuring a dove carrying {@link Sacramental bread|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sacramental_bread}. The Minor Arcana are illustrated with allegorical scenes by Smith, where earlier decks, with a few rare exceptions, had simple designs for the Minor Arcana.

The symbols and imagery used in the deck were influenced by the 19th-century magician and occultist {@link Eliphas Levi|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eliphas_Levi}, as well as by the teachings of the {@link Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hermetic_Order_of_the_Golden_Dawn}. In order to accommodate the {@link astrological|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astrology} correspondences taught by the Golden Dawn, Waite introduced several innovations to the deck. He switched the order of the Strength and Justice cards so that Strength corresponded with {@link Leo|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leo_(astrology)} and Justice corresponded with {@link Libra|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Libra_(astrology)}. He based '{@link the Lovers|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Lovers}' card on Italian tarot decks, which have two persons and an angel, to reinforce its correspondence with {@link Gemini|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gemini_(astrology)}.

entries.name: The Major Arcana
entries: The Major Arcana are the named cards in a {@link cartomantic tarot pack|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tarot#Cartomancy}. There are usually 22 such cards in a standard 78-card pack, typically numbered from 0 to 21 (or 1 to 21, with the Fool being left unnumbered). Although the cards correspond to the {@link trump cards|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tarot_card_game} of a pack used for playing tarot card game, the term 'Major Arcana' is rarely used by players and is typically associated exclusively with use for {@link divination|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Divination} by {@link occultists|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occultist}.

entries.name: The Minor Arcana
entries: The Minor Arcana, sometimes known as the Lesser Arcana, are the {@link suit cards|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suit_(cards)} in a {@link cartomantic tarot deck|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cartomancy}.

Cartomantic tarot cards emerged in France in the late 18th century, popularised by occultists such as {@link Etteilla|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Etteilla}. The terms Major and Minor Arcana originate with {@link Jean-Baptiste Pitois|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Pitois} (1811-1877), {@link nom de plume|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nom_de_plume} Paul Christian.

In their contemporary versions, the Minor Arcana are often illustratedâ€”a convention popularized by the Rider-Waite tarot in 1910. Used in a tarot card reading in conjunction with the Major Arcana, the cards of the Minor Arcana suggest subtleties and details, and signify day-to-day insights.
{@i Text from {@link Wikipedia|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rider%E2%80%93Waite_Tarot}}

card.name: Ace of Wands
entries: {@i Inspiration, Creation, Energy}
The Ace of Wands symbolizes an initial burst of inspiration and the raw potential to create or initiate a new endeavor. It encourages embracing opportunities with enthusiasm and passion.

card.name: Two of Wands
entries: {@i Planning, Decisions, Progress}
The Two of Wands represents thoughtful planning and careful decision-making about the future. It suggests evaluating one's ambitions and setting clear intentions to progress toward goals.

card.name: Three of Wands
entries: {@i Expansion, Exploration, Foresight}
The Three of Wands indicates a time of growth and exploring broader horizons. It encourages anticipation and confidence as efforts begin to yield promising results.

card.name: Four of Wands
entries: {@i Celebration, Harmony, Community}
The Four of Wands signifies celebration, joy, and communal harmony. It highlights enjoying milestones and fostering strong bonds within a supportive environment.

card.name: Five of Wands
entries: {@i Competition, Conflict, Challenges}
The Five of Wands reflects a period of rivalry or minor conflicts that stimulate growth. It advises navigating these challenges constructively to foster personal improvement.

card.name: Six of Wands
entries: {@i Victory, Recognition, Confidence}
The Six of Wands symbolizes triumph and public acknowledgment of one's achievements. It emphasizes confidence gained through success and recognition.

card.name: Seven of Wands
entries: {@i Defense, Perseverance, Standing Ground}
The Seven of Wands highlights perseverance and the need to defend one's position or beliefs. It suggests maintaining resolve in the face of opposition.

card.name: Eight of Wands
entries: {@i Action, Speed, Movement}
The Eight of Wands represents rapid movement, swift changes, or quick progress. It urges readiness to act decisively and embrace momentum when opportunities arise.

card.name: Nine of Wands
entries: {@i Resilience, Endurance, Caution}
The Nine of Wands symbolizes endurance and resilience despite past struggles. It advises remaining cautious yet persistent, acknowledging strength gained from previous trials.

card.name: Ten of Wands
entries: {@i Burden, Responsibility, Completion}
The Ten of Wands indicates heavy responsibilities or burdens nearing completion. It emphasizes recognizing one's limits and seeking balance to avoid burnout.

card.name: Page of Wands
entries: {@i Exploration, Enthusiasm, Discovery}
The Page of Wands embodies youthful curiosity and enthusiasm for discovery. It suggests openness to new experiences and eagerness to pursue creative ideas.

card.name: Knight of Wands
entries: {@i Adventure, Passion, Impulsivity}
The Knight of Wands represents an adventurous spirit driven by passion and impulsiveness. It encourages embracing new ventures with vigor but advises moderation to avoid recklessness.

card.name: Queen of Wands
entries: {@i Confidence, Charisma, Determination}
The Queen of Wands embodies self-assuredness, charm, and unwavering determination. She represents strong leadership and the ability to inspire and uplift others.

card.name: King of Wands
entries: {@i Leadership, Vision, Courage}
The King of Wands symbolizes visionary leadership, courage, and decisiveness. He encourages bold actions driven by clear vision and unwavering ambition.

card.name: Ace of Cups
entries: {@i Love, Emotion, Intuition}
The Ace of Cups symbolizes emotional renewal, deep connections, and new feelings. It suggests openness to emotional experiences and the potential for fulfilling relationships.

card.name: Two of Cups
entries: {@i Partnership, Unity, Harmony}
The Two of Cups signifies mutual attraction and emotional unity. It emphasizes the importance of balanced partnerships and harmonious relationships built on mutual respect.

card.name: Three of Cups
entries: {@i Celebration, Friendship, Community}
The Three of Cups highlights joyous celebrations and the supportive bond of friendships. It suggests sharing happiness with others and strengthening social connections.

card.name: Four of Cups
entries: {@i Contemplation, Apathy, Reevaluation}
The Four of Cups represents introspection and reevaluating emotional satisfaction. It advises being mindful of apathy and appreciating existing opportunities.

card.name: Five of Cups
entries: {@i Loss, Grief, Regret}
The Five of Cups symbolizes emotional setbacks and mourning loss. It advises acknowledging grief but also encourages seeing potential and hope in what remains.

card.name: Six of Cups
entries: {@i Nostalgia, Innocence, Reunion}
The Six of Cups reflects nostalgic emotions and memories. It suggests reconnecting with the innocence of past experiences or reuniting with familiar comforts.

card.name: Seven of Cups
entries: {@i Choices, Illusion, Imagination}
The Seven of Cups indicates multiple choices, imaginative possibilities, and potential illusions. It advises discernment in distinguishing between realistic goals and fanciful dreams.

card.name: Eight of Cups
entries: {@i Withdrawal, Abandonment, Transition}
The Eight of Cups represents the emotional decision to move on from unfulfilling situations. It encourages seeking deeper meaning by leaving behind what no longer satisfies.

card.name: Nine of Cups
entries: {@i Satisfaction, Wishes, Contentment}
The Nine of Cups signifies emotional fulfillment and satisfaction. It symbolizes achieving personal happiness and experiencing the joy of having one's wishes realized.

card.name: Ten of Cups
entries: {@i Harmony, Family, Happiness}
The Ten of Cups embodies emotional harmony, happiness, and familial unity. It represents a period of peace and contentment shared with loved ones.

card.name: Page of Cups
entries: {@i Curiosity, Creativity, Sensitivity}
The Page of Cups symbolizes youthful curiosity, creative exploration, and emotional sensitivity. It suggests being open to imaginative possibilities and intuitive insights.

card.name: Knight of Cups
entries: {@i Romance, Idealism, Adventure}
The Knight of Cups embodies romantic pursuit, emotional idealism, and adventurous spirit. It encourages pursuing dreams and embracing emotional experiences openly and passionately.

card.name: Queen of Cups
entries: {@i Compassion, Intuition, Empathy}
The Queen of Cups symbolizes deep emotional understanding, compassion, and empathy. She represents nurturing intuition and emotional guidance, creating harmonious connections.

card.name: King of Cups
entries: {@i Emotional Balance, Diplomacy, Wisdom}
The King of Cups embodies emotional maturity, balance, and diplomatic wisdom. He encourages managing emotions wisely and guiding others with compassionate understanding.

card.name: Ace of Swords
entries: {@i Clarity, Truth, Breakthrough}
The Ace of Swords symbolizes clear thinking and decisive breakthroughs. It highlights the power of intellect and encourages truthful communication.

card.name: Two of Swords
entries: {@i Indecision, Balance, Stalemate}
The Two of Swords represents difficult decisions and internal conflict. It suggests the need to balance logic and emotions to move beyond a stalemate.

card.name: Three of Swords
entries: {@i Heartbreak, Sorrow, Betrayal}
The Three of Swords signifies emotional pain and sorrow. It represents confronting harsh truths and encourages healing through acknowledgment of pain.

card.name: Four of Swords
entries: {@i Rest, Recovery, Reflection}
The Four of Swords symbolizes rest and recuperation. It advises taking time for recovery and deep reflection after periods of stress or conflict.

card.name: Five of Swords
entries: {@i Conflict, Defeat, Self-interest}
The Five of Swords reflects conflict and difficult victories. It cautions against actions driven by self-interest that may harm relationships or integrity.

card.name: Six of Swords
entries: {@i Transition, Release, Moving On}
The Six of Swords represents moving away from difficulties toward calmer conditions. It encourages embracing transitions and leaving behind past hardships.

card.name: Seven of Swords
entries: {@i Deception, Strategy, Resourcefulness}
The Seven of Swords symbolizes clever strategy or deception. It advises caution and awareness, highlighting the importance of integrity despite temptations.

card.name: Eight of Swords
entries: {@i Restriction, Imprisonment, Powerlessness}
The Eight of Swords represents feelings of restriction or helplessness. It emphasizes recognizing self-imposed limitations and finding ways to regain personal freedom.

card.name: Nine of Swords
entries: {@i Anxiety, Fear, Worry}
The Nine of Swords signifies intense anxiety and fear. It advises confronting inner worries directly to overcome their influence and regain emotional stability.

card.name: Ten of Swords
entries: {@i Endings, Defeat, Renewal}
The Ten of Swords symbolizes a painful but definitive ending. It highlights the necessity of accepting closure to facilitate renewal and recovery.

card.name: Page of Swords
entries: {@i Curiosity, Alertness, Communication}
The Page of Swords embodies youthful curiosity, alertness, and clear communication. It encourages asking questions and gathering information to build understanding.

card.name: Knight of Swords
entries: {@i Action, Ambition, Determination}
The Knight of Swords represents bold action and strong ambition. It emphasizes determination in pursuing goals but cautions against impulsive decisions.

card.name: Queen of Swords
entries: {@i Perception, Independence, Clarity}
The Queen of Swords symbolizes keen perception, independent thinking, and clear communication. She encourages approaching situations with honesty and rational clarity.

card.name: King of Swords
entries: {@i Authority, Truth, Intellectual Power}
The King of Swords embodies intellectual strength, authoritative clarity, and ethical judgment. He advises using reason and fairness when making decisions.

card.name: Ace of Pentacles
entries: {@i Opportunity, Prosperity, New Ventures}
The Ace of Pentacles symbolizes promising opportunities and material prosperity. It suggests the potential for new ventures that can lead to abundance.

card.name: Two of Pentacles
entries: {@i Balance, Adaptability, Management}
The Two of Pentacles represents managing multiple priorities and maintaining balance. It advises flexibility and adaptability when handling responsibilities.

card.name: Three of Pentacles
entries: {@i Teamwork, Collaboration, Skill}
The Three of Pentacles emphasizes collaboration and teamwork. It symbolizes the importance of collective effort and skillful contribution towards a common goal.

card.name: Four of Pentacles
entries: {@i Security, Conservatism, Control}
The Four of Pentacles signifies a focus on security and financial stability. It advises moderation, warning against excessive control or fear of loss.

card.name: Five of Pentacles
entries: {@i Hardship, Loss, Isolation}
The Five of Pentacles symbolizes experiencing hardship or financial difficulty. It encourages seeking support and recognizing opportunities for relief.

card.name: Six of Pentacles
entries: {@i Generosity, Charity, Reciprocity}
The Six of Pentacles highlights generosity and mutual assistance. It represents both giving and receiving support in balanced and fair exchanges.

card.name: Seven of Pentacles
entries: {@i Assessment, Patience, Reward}
The Seven of Pentacles represents assessing progress and patiently awaiting rewards. It advises reflecting on efforts and adjusting plans for future growth.

card.name: Eight of Pentacles
entries: {@i Mastery, Diligence, Dedication}
The Eight of Pentacles symbolizes diligent effort and mastery of skills. It encourages dedication to one's craft and continual improvement.

card.name: Nine of Pentacles
entries: {@i Independence, Luxury, Achievement}
The Nine of Pentacles signifies independence, comfort, and material success. It represents personal achievement and the enjoyment of life's finer things.

card.name: Ten of Pentacles
entries: {@i Legacy, Wealth, Family}
The Ten of Pentacles symbolizes lasting wealth, family legacy, and stability. It highlights the importance of security and continuity across generations.

card.name: Page of Pentacles
entries: {@i Ambition, Learning, Practicality}
The Page of Pentacles represents ambition, practicality, and a desire for learning. It encourages pursuing knowledge and new skills with a grounded approach.

card.name: Knight of Pentacles
entries: {@i Reliability, Patience, Efficiency}
The Knight of Pentacles symbolizes reliability and careful planning. It emphasizes steady, patient effort and methodical approaches to achieving goals.

card.name: Queen of Pentacles
entries: {@i Nurturing, Practicality, Abundance}
The Queen of Pentacles embodies nurturing, practicality, and material comfort. She symbolizes a balanced approach to managing resources and supporting others.

card.name: King of Pentacles
entries: {@i Prosperity, Security, Leadership}
The King of Pentacles represents prosperity, security, and effective leadership. He symbolizes mastery in creating and maintaining wealth and stability.

card.name: The Fool
entries: {@i Folly, Freedom, Potential}
The Fool embodies pure potential, stepping forward with innocence and openness. It highlights the unlimited possibilities and the adventurous spirit that explores beyond the known.

card.name: The Magician
entries: {@i Skill, Manifestation, Willpower}
The Magician represents focused intention and the power to manifest one's desires. It symbolizes the mastery of using resources effectively to bridge spiritual ideas and physical realities.

card.name: The High Priestess
entries: {@i Mystery, Intuition, Inner Voice}
The High Priestess signifies deep intuition and the hidden aspects of the psyche. She encourages accessing one's inner wisdom to reveal insights beyond surface-level perceptions.

card.name: The Empress
entries: {@i Fertility, Abundance, Nurturing}
The Empress symbolizes creativity, nurturing, and natural abundance. She represents a fertile and supportive environment necessary for growth and harmony.

card.name: The Emperor
entries: {@i Authority, Structure, Control}
The Emperor embodies structured authority and stability, symbolizing the importance of discipline and strong leadership in achieving goals.

card.name: The Hierophant
entries: {@i Tradition, Belief, Conformity}
The Hierophant represents structured traditions and collective beliefs, highlighting the guidance found in cultural wisdom and societal frameworks.

card.name: The Lovers
entries: {@i Love, Union, Choices}
The Lovers embody harmony in relationships and the importance of significant choices. The card emphasizes moral decisions and the deep connections formed through commitment.

card.name: The Chariot
entries: {@i Triumph, Determination, Control}
The Chariot signifies the victory achieved through determination and self-discipline. It reflects the power of focused will to overcome challenges.

card.name: Strength
entries: {@i Courage, Patience, Inner Power}
Strength symbolizes inner resilience, compassionate courage, and the calm control of primal instincts. It demonstrates that true strength lies in gentle perseverance.

card.name: The Hermit
entries: {@i Solitude, Introspection, Wisdom}
The Hermit emphasizes seeking deeper wisdom through introspection and solitude. It advises withdrawing from external distractions to discover inner truths.

card.name: Wheel of Fortune
entries: {@i Change, Destiny, Cycles}
The Wheel of Fortune highlights the cyclical nature of life, underscoring inevitable change and the interconnectedness of events. It suggests adaptability to life's unfolding patterns.

card.name: Justice
entries: {@i Truth, Fairness, Law}
Justice embodies fairness and balanced evaluation. It urges an impartial assessment of situations, ensuring actions are aligned with ethical standards.

card.name: The Hanged Man
entries: {@i Sacrifice, Release, New Perspectives}
The Hanged Man represents the need for surrender and letting go to gain new insights. It highlights that clarity often comes from viewing situations from an entirely different perspective.

card.name: Death
entries: {@i Transformation, Endings, Rebirth}
Death signifies profound change and the necessary end of one phase to usher in renewal. It embodies transformation as a vital part of personal growth.

card.name: Temperance
entries: {@i Moderation, Balance, Harmony}
Temperance symbolizes harmony achieved through balance and moderation. It encourages patience and the blending of different elements to create equilibrium.

card.name: The Devil
entries: {@i Bondage, Temptation, Materialism}
The Devil signifies the power of illusion, material attachment, and the seductive nature of temptation. It emphasizes recognizing unhealthy bonds and breaking free from self-imposed limitations.

card.name: The Tower
entries: {@i Upheaval, Crisis, Revelation}

The Tower signifies sudden and unexpected events that strip away illusions, leaving reality starkly visible. It represents the challenging yet liberating moments when truth emerges, often through disruption.

card.name: The Star
entries: {@i Hope, Inspiration, Renewal}
The Star appears as a guiding light after turmoil, offering clarity and encouraging optimism for the future. It suggests a deep inner peace and the gentle reassurance that better times lie ahead.

card.name: The Moon
entries: {@i Illusion, Intuition, Subconscious}
The Moon calls attention to the hidden layers of perception and the complexities of emotions. It advises trusting one's inner voice and intuition to navigate uncertainties and ambiguities.

card.name: The Sun
entries: {@i Joy, Success, Vitality}
The Sun brings warmth, clarity, and an abundance of positive energy. It suggests that a period of growth, confidence, and prosperity is at hand, encouraging a joyful embrace of life's opportunities.

card.name: Judgement
entries: {@i Reflection, Reckoning, Rebirth}
Judgement emphasizes a moment of profound clarity and awakening, encouraging a sincere evaluation of one's past choices and actions. It heralds the potential for profound personal transformation.

card.name: The World
entries: {@i Completion, Wholeness, Fulfillment}

The World marks the harmonious conclusion of a journey, symbolizing the integration of experiences into a balanced whole. It represents satisfaction, unity, and the realization of one's efforts and aspirations.
